elements.title: Incremental Armor-Shedding Listing Wizard
elements.problem: The host must expose their private domestic space — the physical manifestation of their hero system — to public scrutiny. Uploading photos, writing descriptions, and setting house rules forces the host through Perls' impasse layer where they confront that a stranger will inhabit their sanctuary. If the totality of this exposure is presented at once, the host's character defenses collapse and they abandon the listing.
elements.solution: Fragment the existential act of self-exposure into 5-6 discrete, non-threatening wizard steps that function as what Becker calls 'manageable pieces.' Each step removes one thin layer of character armor while simultaneously providing a platform-mediated replacement defense (progress indicator, saved state, pre-populated defaults). The completion percentage badge on the listing card converts overwhelming vulnerability into a simple, actionable number — transforming terror into a to-do list.

evidence.quote: He doesn't bite the world off in one piece as a giant would, but in small manageable pieces, as a beaver does. He uses all kinds of techniques, which we call the 'character defenses': he learns not to expose himself, not to stand out.
evidence.insight: The listing wizard must fragment the act of self-exposure into beaver-sized pieces. Each wizard step is a character defense that represses the totality of what the host is doing.

evidence.quote: Completion percentage is a good host nudge. Hosts need to know what's unfinished before a listing goes live. A visible progress indicator on the listing card creates just enough friction to get them to finish — without being in the way.
evidence.insight: The completion percentage converts the existential weight of self-exposure into a manageable numeric signal — a character defense externalized as UI.

evidence.quote: The third layer is a stiff one to penetrate: it is the 'impasse' that covers our feeling of being empty and lost... Underneath this layer is the fourth and most baffling one: the 'death' or fear-of-death layer.
evidence.insight: Photo upload and house rules are the impasse layer of listing creation. The wizard must move the host through these steps quickly, not letting them linger in existential confrontation.

elements.user_goal: List my space without feeling like I'm surrendering control of my home to strangers
elements.company_goal: Maximize listing completion rate by reducing wizard abandonment at emotionally charged steps (photos, house rules)
elements.time_budget: 8-12 minutes across all wizard steps; no single step should exceed 2 minutes of active effort
anti_goals: Do not present all listing fields on a single page — this forces the host to confront the totality of exposure at once
Do not require photo upload as the first step — ease the host in with text-based steps before demanding visual exposure
Do not show 'X people viewed your listing' before the host is psychologically ready for public scrutiny
elements.success_metric: Wizard completion rate exceeds 70%; drop-off rate at photo upload step stays below 25%

elements.title: Pause-as-Armor Listing State
elements.problem: Hosts who cannot sustain the vulnerability of active listing face a binary choice: remain exposed (listing live) or destroy the character work already invested (delete). This binary triggers what Becker calls the grief of destroying a hero system built at existential cost. Hosts who delete regret it; hosts who feel trapped by a live listing resent the platform.
elements.solution: Provide a 'Pause' state that preserves the listing in suspended animation — all photos, rules, and settings intact, but invisible to guests. Pause functions as Becker's middle path between the terror of continued exposure and the grief of total retreat. It allows the host to maintain the vital lie that they are 'still a host' without bearing the active cost of stranger-availability. The pause action must be more prominent and easier to reach than delete.

evidence.quote: Pause matters more than delete. Hosts who stop a listing aren't always done with it. Pause preserves the work, keeps the door open, and costs nothing. Delete is a one-way door that creates regret.
evidence.insight: Pause is the Beckerian middle path — it preserves the new hero system in suspended animation rather than forcing a binary death-or-exposure choice.

evidence.quote: Repression is not simply a negative force opposing life energies; it lives on life energies and uses them creatively.
evidence.insight: The pause function repurposes the host's anxiety into a productive holding pattern rather than destructive flight. It is repression made creative — the host can retreat without regressing.

elements.user_goal: Step back from hosting without losing everything I built
elements.company_goal: Retain listing inventory by converting would-be deletions into pauses; increase re-activation rate from paused hosts
elements.time_budget: 1-tap pause action; resume should require no more than a quick review before going live again
anti_goals: Do not make delete the default or equally prominent action alongside pause
Do not require hosts to explain why they are pausing — this forces confrontation with anxiety they are trying to manage
Do not send 'We miss you' re-activation emails within the first 2 weeks of pausing — respect the retreat
elements.success_metric: Pause-to-delete ratio exceeds 3:1; paused listings re-activate within 60 days at >40% rate

elements.title: Stranger-Vetting Proposal Interface
elements.problem: The host must decide whether to allow a specific, named stranger into the physical space that constitutes their primary hero system. Becker writes about 'billions of individual organismic appetites' — accepting a proposal means voluntarily inviting one such appetite into the sanctuary. If the proposal provides insufficient information about the stranger, the host feels 'forsaken by the protecting superego' and the terror of uncontrollable intrusion becomes unmanageable.
elements.solution: Structure the proposal view as a comprehensive stranger-vetting interface that provides what Becker calls 'delegated powers.' Display guest verification status, review history from prior hosts, stay count, and a structured intent summary (dates, schedule, purpose) above the fold. An experienced guest's track record functions as borrowed character armor — past hosts' survival becomes the current host's confidence. The counter-offer mechanism allows the host to assert temporal control (shortening duration) as a character defense against unbounded vulnerability.

evidence.quote: When someone who's already used Split Lease applies to a host who's never had a guest, that guest's reputation does the selling. Their history, their reviews, their familiarity with how things work — it all reduces the host's anxiety.
evidence.insight: Cross-activation in proposal management is Becker's delegated power: one host's successful survival of the stranger becomes the next host's character armor.

evidence.quote: Each thing, in order to deliciously expand, is forever gobbling up others. Appetites may be innocent because they are naturally given, but any organism caught in the myriad cross-purposes of this planet is a potential victim of this very innocence.
evidence.insight: The guest's innocent need for housing is, from the host's unconscious perspective, an appetite that threatens their sanctuary. The proposal interface must make this appetite feel contained and predictable.

evidence.quote: A well-structured proposal — clear dates, schedule, pricing, intent — activates the host to respond. A vague or incomplete one creates friction.
evidence.insight: Proposal structure is character armor for the host — each filled field is a piece of information that reduces the stranger from terrifying unknown to manageable known.

elements.user_goal: Know enough about this stranger to feel safe letting them into my home
elements.company_goal: Increase proposal acceptance rate by reducing host anxiety through information completeness and guest credibility signals
elements.time_budget: Host should be able to assess a proposal and reach a decision within 3-5 minutes; critical vetting information visible within first 10 seconds
anti_goals: Do not present proposals as anonymous or information-sparse — this amplifies stranger-terror
Do not auto-accept proposals on behalf of the host — this removes the control that constitutes their character defense
Do not hide the counter-offer mechanism behind secondary navigation — it is the host's primary anxiety-management tool
elements.success_metric: Proposal response time under 24 hours; acceptance rate exceeds 55%; counter-offer completion rate (vs. abandonment) exceeds 80%

elements.title: Default-Delegated Pricing Engine
elements.problem: Setting a price forces the host to assign monetary value to something psychologically priceless — their home, their sanctuary, the material expression of their vital lie. Pricing too high is a defense mechanism (making the space unaffordable protects it from invasion); pricing too low triggers self-deprecation anxiety. The host lacks both market knowledge and emotional capacity to make this decision alone.
elements.solution: Pre-populate pricing with algorithmically generated defaults that the host can review and accept with a single confirmation. The default functions as the platform delegating the 'courage to be' — absorbing the existential burden of self-valuation on the host's behalf. Show the default alongside a local market range (min-max) so the host can see their space is valued fairly without having to generate the number themselves. A 'guaranteed income' projection anchored to the default converts terrifying uncertainty into predictable, controlled revenue.

evidence.quote: Man could strut and boast all he wanted, but he really drew his 'courage to be' from a god, a string of sexual conquests, a Big Brother, a flag, the proletariat, and the fetish of money and the size of a bank balance.
evidence.insight: Pricing inverts the courage-from-money flow: the host must convert courage into a monetary figure. The platform must absorb this burden through defaults that say 'this is what you are worth.'

evidence.quote: We tend to be afraid of any knowledge that could cause us to despise ourselves or to make us feel inferior, weak, worthless, evil, shameful.
evidence.insight: An underpriced listing is a direct assault on self-esteem. Defaults must be calibrated to validate the host's sense of worth while remaining market-competitive.

evidence.quote: Value before the ask — always. Any flow that requires users to give information before seeing results will lose most of them.
evidence.insight: Show the pricing default before asking the host to evaluate or override it. The value (the number) must come before the ask (do you agree?).

elements.user_goal: Know my space is priced fairly without having to figure it out myself
elements.company_goal: Minimize pricing-step abandonment; ensure default acceptance rates support marketplace liquidity
elements.time_budget: Under 60 seconds for hosts who accept defaults; under 3 minutes for those who adjust
anti_goals: Do not present an empty price field — this forces the host into the existential void of self-valuation
Do not show competitor pricing that might trigger self-deprecation or defensive overpricing
Do not display the platform's fee percentage before the host has seen and accepted the gross price — fee revelation during self-valuation amplifies betrayal anxiety
elements.success_metric: Default acceptance rate exceeds 65%; pricing-step drop-off stays below 15%; time-on-step under 90 seconds average

elements.title: Ritual Control Dashboard for Active Lease
elements.problem: During active lease, a stranger physically inhabits the host's hero system. The host's vital lie — that they control their domestic world — is under constant low-grade threat. Without a centralized control interface, the host's self-preservation instinct has no outlet, leading to chronic anxiety, micromanagement through messaging, or premature lease termination.
elements.solution: Provide an urgency-first dashboard that surfaces pending actions (arrival confirmations, cleaning photo reviews, date change requests, unread messages) as the host's primary view. Each dashboard item is a micro-ritual of control — a Beckerian 'way of the world' that maintains the host's equanimity. The cleaning photo review workflow is particularly critical: it provides proof that the space has survived contact with the stranger and been restored, functioning as ritual purification that allows repression to re-engage after each stay cycle.

evidence.quote: Urgency should surface first on the dashboard. Unread proposals, pending actions, incomplete listings — that's what a host needs to see the moment they log in.
evidence.insight: The urgency dashboard is a Beckerian 'manageable world' reduced to a screen — it converts the diffuse anxiety of stranger-in-home into discrete, actionable items.

evidence.quote: Such constant expenditure of psychological energy on the business of preserving life would be impossible if the fear of death were not as constant. The very term 'self-preservation' implies an effort against some force of disintegration.
evidence.insight: The dashboard is the externalization of the host's self-preservation instinct. Its constant availability mirrors the constancy of the underlying threat.

evidence.quote: All he has to do is to plunge ahead in a compulsive style of drivenness in the 'ways of the world' that the child learns and in which he lives later as a kind of grim equanimity.
evidence.insight: Dashboard micro-rituals (review photos, confirm arrival, respond to message) provide the compulsive drivenness that maintains equanimity during the sustained vulnerability of active lease.

elements.user_goal: Know at a glance that everything is under control with my space and my guest
elements.company_goal: Reduce host churn during active lease by providing continuous sense of control; increase host engagement and response times
elements.time_budget: Dashboard loads in under 2 seconds; host processes all urgent items in under 5 minutes per session
anti_goals: Do not bury urgent actions behind navigation — every login must immediately surface what needs attention
Do not show 'nothing to do' as empty state — provide reassurance signals (next stay date, income earned, positive review snippets) to sustain the vital lie when no actions are pending
Do not auto-dismiss cleaning photo reviews — the host must actively confirm the space is restored
elements.success_metric: Host dashboard visit frequency exceeds 3x/week during active lease; urgent action response time under 12 hours; host-initiated early termination rate stays below 5%

elements.title: Immortality-Project Retention Loop
elements.problem: After a lease ends, the host must decide whether to rebuild their vital lie around hosting (re-list) or retreat to pre-hosting character armor. The host who has successfully completed a lease has been more 'fully alive' — more exposed, vulnerable, engaged — than before. But Becker warns that 'the deepest need is to be free of the anxiety of death and annihilation; but it is life itself which awakens it.' The host may shrink back from sustained aliveness.
elements.solution: At lease completion, present a Hosting Legacy Summary that reframes the hosting experience as an immortality project — a contribution that transcends the individual transaction. Show cumulative impact metrics (total guests hosted, income earned, positive reviews received, months of housing provided) that position the host as part of something larger than themselves. This is Becker's 'embedding in other-power' reframed as legacy. The re-listing flow must be a streamlined 1-2 step process that reuses existing listing data, reducing the character-work cost of recommitment. Offer an 'auto-renew' option that removes the conscious decision point entirely, allowing the vital lie to continue without active confrontation.

evidence.quote: The irony of man's condition is that the deepest need is to be free of the anxiety of death and annihilation; but it is life itself which awakens it, and so we must shrink from being fully alive.
evidence.insight: Retention asks: can the host sustain aliveness? The legacy summary provides narcissistic supply — the host is not just exposed, they are contributing to something that outlasts them.

evidence.quote: The neurotic who has had therapy is like a member of Alcoholics Anonymous: he can never take his cure for granted, and the best sign of the genuineness of that cure is that he lives with humility.
evidence.insight: The returning host cannot take their comfort with hosting for granted. The re-listing flow must be humble and low-effort, not triumphant — acknowledging the ongoing courage required.

evidence.quote: Pause matters more than delete. Hosts who stop a listing aren't always done with it. Pause preserves the work, keeps the door open, and costs nothing.
evidence.insight: At the retention decision point, pause should be offered as the default alternative to re-listing — not delete. This preserves the host's option to return without forcing immediate recommitment.

elements.user_goal: Feel that my hosting mattered and that continuing is worth the vulnerability
elements.company_goal: Maximize host re-listing rate; reduce time between lease end and re-activation; build long-term host identity on the platform
elements.time_budget: Legacy summary consumed in under 2 minutes; re-listing completed in under 3 minutes using existing data
anti_goals: Do not send re-listing prompts before the host has had time to process the lease ending — respect the post-exposure integration period
Do not show the re-listing flow as identical to initial listing creation — the returning host must feel their prior work is honored
Do not present retention as purely financial — the host needs meaning, not just money, to sustain the vulnerability
elements.success_metric: Re-listing rate exceeds 60% within 90 days of lease end; paused-to-relisted conversion exceeds 40%; average time to re-list under 14 days
